question: A.01 [1.0 point] All atoms of a given element have the same ___________.

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Handbook, Volume 1, Module 1, pg. 4
Incorrect. REF: DOE Handbook, Volume 1, Module 1, pg. 4
Correct. REF: DOE Handbook, Volume 1, Module 1, pg. 4
Incorrect. REF: DOE Handbook, Volume 1, Module 1, pg. 4

question: A.02 [1.0 point] The use of a reflector results in _________.

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone & Sesonske, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Section 4.46-4.48, pg. 170-171

answers.answer: b. A high neutron absorption cross section.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone & Sesonske, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Section 4.46-4.48, pg. 170-171

answers.answer: c. A decrease in the critical mass of fissile material.
answers.feedback: Correct. REF: Glasstone & Sesonske, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Section 4.46-4.48, pg. 170-171

answers.answer: d. The decrease of the average power output for a given peak neutron flux.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone & Sesonske, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Section 4.46-4.48, pg. 170-171

question: A.03 [1.0 point] The following graph for U-235 shows……

answers.answer: a. Differential rod worth curve in the core.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Manual Vol. 1, NP-01, pg. 57

answers.answer: b. Distribution of fission product yield.
answers.feedback: Correct. REF: DOE Manual Vol. 1, NP-01, pg. 57

answers.answer: c. Radial flux distribution in the core.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Manual Vol. 1, NP-01, pg. 57

answers.answer: d. Neutron energy distribution in the moderator.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Manual Vol. 1, NP-01, pg. 57

question: A.05 [1.0 point] ___________ is the total distance in centimeters traveled in 1 second by all the neutrons present in 1 cm3.

answers.feedback: Correct. REF: Glasstone & Sesonske, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Section 2.118, pg. 72
Incorrect. REF: Glasstone & Sesonske, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Section 2.118, pg. 72
Incorrect. REF: Glasstone & Sesonske, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Section 2.118, pg. 72
Incorrect. REF: Glasstone & Sesonske, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Section 2.118, pg. 72

question: A.06 [1.0 point] Most text books list β for a U235 fueled reactor as 0.0065 ∆K/K and βeff as being 0.0075 ∆K/K. Why is βeff larger than β?

answers.answer: a. Delayed neutrons are born at higher energies than prompt neutrons resulting in a greater worth for these neutrons.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burns, Section 3.2.4, pg. 3-12

answers.answer: b. Delayed neutrons are born at lower energies than prompt neutrons resulting in a less loss due to leakage for these neutrons.
answers.feedback: Correct. REF: Burns, Section 3.2.4, pg. 3-12

answers.answer: c. The fuel includes U238 which has a relatively large for fast fission.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burns, Section 3.2.4, pg. 3-12

answers.answer: d. Some U238 in the core becomes Pu239 (by neutron absorption) which has a larger for fission.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burns, Section 3.2.4, pg. 3-12

question: A.07 [1.0 point] As the moderator temperature increases, the resonance escape probability ____________.

answers.answer: a. Increases, since the moderator becomes less dense.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burns, Section 3.3.2, pg. 3-18

answers.answer: b. Decreases, since neutrons are more likely to be absorbed by U-238 and Pu-240.
answers.feedback: Correct. REF: Burns, Section 3.3.2, pg. 3-18

answers.answer: c. Remains constant, since the effect of moderator temperature change is relatively small.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burns, Section 3.3.2, pg. 3-18

answers.answer: d. Increases, since the moderator-to-fuel ratio increases.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burns, Section 3.3.2, pg. 3-18

question: A.08 [1.0 point] Two minutes following shutdown, reactor power is at 10 kW and decreases with a constant reactor period. Which ONE of the following is the correct power for three minutes later?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: P = Poet/τ   P = 10 kW* e180/-80     P = 10 kW *0.105 =  1.05 kW
Correct. REF: P = Poet/τ   P = 10 kW* e180/-80     P = 10 kW *0.105 =  1.05 kW
Incorrect. REF: P = Poet/τ   P = 10 kW* e180/-80     P = 10 kW *0.105 =  1.05 kW
Incorrect. REF: P = Poet/τ   P = 10 kW* e180/-80     P = 10 kW *0.105 =  1.05 kW

Incorrect. REF: Knief, Nuclear Engineering, 2nd ed., pg. 142

question: A.10 [1.0 point] During the minutes following a reactor scram, reactor power decreases on a negative 80 second period, corresponding to the half-life of the longest lived delayed neutron precursor, which is approximately __________.

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burns, Section 1.3.3, pg. 1-6 and 1-7
Incorrect. REF: Burns, Section 1.3.3, pg. 1-6 and 1-7
Correct. REF: Burns, Section 1.3.3, pg. 1-6 and 1-7
Incorrect. REF: Burns, Section 1.3.3, pg. 1-6 and 1-7

question: A.11 [1.0 point] During a Subcritical Multiplication "1/M" plot, data is required to be taken. What does the 1/M represent?

answers.answer: a. The inverse of fuel elements presented in the core.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Handbook, Volume 2, Module 4, “Subcritical Multiplication”, pg. 1-9

answers.answer: b. The inverse of the moderator coefficient of reactivity.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Handbook, Volume 2, Module 4, “Subcritical Multiplication”, pg. 1-9

answers.answer: c. The inverse migration length of neutrons of varying energies.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Handbook, Volume 2, Module 4, “Subcritical Multiplication”, pg. 1-9

answers.answer: d. The inverse multiplication of the count rate between generations.
answers.feedback: Correct. REF: DOE Handbook, Volume 2, Module 4, “Subcritical Multiplication”, pg. 1-9

question: A.14 [1.0 point] The reactor is critical at 5 watts. Which ONE of the following correctly describes the reactor behavior when a reactivity worth of 0.50 % ∆K/K is IMMEDIATELY inserted to the reactor core?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, Section 4.2, Figure 4-1, pg. 4-2; 0.5 % ∆K/K = 0.005 ∆K/K = ρ, ρ > 0; ρ = (keff -1) / keff, then keff = 1.005; When k > 1, ρ > 0 and reactor is supercritical
Incorrect. REF: Burn, Section 4.2, Figure 4-1, pg. 4-2; 0.5 % ∆K/K = 0.005 ∆K/K = ρ, ρ > 0; ρ = (keff -1) / keff, then keff = 1.005; When k > 1, ρ > 0 and reactor is supercritical
Correct. REF: Burn, Section 4.2, Figure 4-1, pg. 4-2; 0.5 % ∆K/K = 0.005 ∆K/K = ρ, ρ > 0; ρ = (keff -1) / keff, then keff = 1.005; When k > 1, ρ > 0 and reactor is supercritical
Incorrect. REF: Burn, Section 4.2, Figure 4-1, pg. 4-2; 0.5 % ∆K/K = 0.005 ∆K/K = ρ, ρ > 0; ρ = (keff -1) / keff, then keff = 1.005; When k > 1, ρ > 0 and reactor is supercritical

question: A.20 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following is the time period in which the Xe135 inventory peaks in the reactor core after a power changer?

answers.answer: a. 4 to 8 hours after a power increase from 50% to 100%.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Lamarsh 3rd ed., Figure 7.14, pg. 381; UT Presentation: Theory and Principles of Operation, Reactor Kinetics: FPPs slide

answers.answer: b. 4 to 8 hours after a power decrease from 100% to 50%.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Lamarsh 3rd ed., Figure 7.14, pg. 381; UT Presentation: Theory and Principles of Operation, Reactor Kinetics: FPPs slide

answers.answer: c. 7 to 18 hours after a startup to 100%.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Lamarsh 3rd ed., Figure 7.14, pg. 381; UT Presentation: Theory and Principles of Operation, Reactor Kinetics: FPPs slide

answers.answer: d. 7 to 18 hours after a shutdown from 100%.
answers.feedback: Correct. REF: Lamarsh 3rd ed., Figure 7.14, pg. 381; UT Presentation: Theory and Principles of Operation, Reactor Kinetics: FPPs slide
